org.orgName: United States Circuit Court For Ninth Judicial Circuit

div1.p: In the Circuit Court of the United States for the District of Washington
In re Char W. Nordstrom for Habeas Corpus vs. Ed W Cudihee
Letter of Hon. C.H. Hanford declining to issue writ
Filed In The U.S. Circuit Court, Dist. of Washington

Sir:-
I return to you, enclosed herewith, the papers in the above entitled matter, which you placed in my hands this day, and I must decline to sign the order which you have requested.

This case having become notorious by the frequency of its appearance before the courts, I am justified in saying that the present application is without merit, and I consider that your contemplated proceeding has but one tendency, and that is, subversive of the laws of the country. I have heretofore twice refused to grant a writ of habeas corpus in behalf of Nordstrom, and the Supreme Court of the United States has in both instances sustained my rulings.

I will not sign another order, either granting or refusing to grant another petition, nor listen to any argument you may wish to present in behalf of this petitioner, nor will I alow another appeal, which may be made a pretext for further delay in executing the sentence of the law in his case. My purpose is to break the endless chain of repeated applications and appeals which makes the administration of the criminal laws a judicial force.
You have my consent to use this letter in any way.

Respectfully,
C.H. Hanford, U.S. District Judge
Filled in the U.S. Circuit court Dist. of Washington Aug 8 1901 A. Reeves Ayres, Clerk, H.M. Walthew, Dep.
